questions.text: A 12 y/o child presents with multiple types of seizures, including atonic seizures and tonic-clonic seizures, along with significant developmental delays. The parents report that the child has been experiencing these seizures since early childhood. Which of the following syndromes is NOT associated with myoclonic seizures?

Match each drug with its preferred use for the corresponding type of seizure. 1. Partial seizures a. Lorazepam 2. Generalized tonic-clonic seizures b. Diazepam 3. Febrile seizures c. Valproate 4. Status epilepticus d. Carbamazepine
questions.explanation:
Type of Seizure

Anti-Epileptic Drugs

Partial or focal seizure

  • Lamotrigine
  • Oxcarbazepine
  • Eslicarbazepine
  • Carbamazepine
  • Phenytoin
  • Levetiracetam

Generalized tonic clonic seizure

  • Valproate
  • Lamotrigine

Absence seizure

  • Ethosuximide
  • Valproate
  • Lamotrigine

Febrile seizure

Diazepam (rectal) (drug of choice)

Status epilepticus

Lorazepam (drug of choice)

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome)

Drug of choice: Valproate > Lamotrigine > Topiramate

Lennox Gestaut syndrome

Valproate (first line drug)

Dravet's syndrome

Valproate (drug of choice)

Infantile spasm ( also known as West syndrome or Hypsarrhythmia)

Occasional episodes:

  • Drug of choice: ACTH hormone +/- glucocorticoids
 

Associated with tuberous sclerosis (lifelong seizures):

  • Drug of choice: Vigabatrin

Pregnancy

  • Levetiracetam (safest in pregnancy)
  • Lamotrigine

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman with a history of seizures and poor medication adherence presents to the ER after a 6-minute seizure followed by another, with impaired consciousness between episodes. She is unresponsive and has labored breathing. What is the preferred drug of choice for her treatment?

A 4 y/o girl presents to the pediatric clinic with a port-wine stain on her forehead and upper eyelid. Her mother reports that she has been experiencing frequent seizures and has some difficulty in school. O/E, the child exhibits unilateral weakness of the left arm. CT imaging reveals tram-track calcifications in the brain. Which condition is most consistent with this presentation?

A 7 y/o boy is brought to the pediatric clinic due to developmental delays and frequent seizures. Upon examination, the following findings were observed. MRI shows subependymal giant cell astrocytomas. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 12 y/o boy presents to the clinic with a history of behavioural changes and progressive seizures following a measles infection at age 2. The neurologist suspects subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE). Which combination of diagnostic findings would confirm the diagnosis according to SSPE diagnostic criteria?

options.label: A
options.text: Typical clinical presentation, elevated CSF measles antibody titers, and normal EEG

options.label: B
options.text: Brain biopsy with characteristic histopathological findings and elevated CSF globulin levels.

options.label: C
options.text: Characteristic EEG findings, elevated CSF globulin levels, and elevated CSF measles antibody titers

options.label: D
options.text: Increased T2 signal on MRI, acellular CSF, and elevated serum measles-specific IgG

questions.correct_answer: C. Characteristic EEG findings, elevated CSF globulin levels, and elevated CSF measles antibody titers

questions.text: A 10 y/o boy presents to the clinic with a year-long history of cognitive decline. His parents report increased irritability, social withdrawal, and difficulty in school. He had measles at age 2. On examination, he shows signs of myoclonus and motor difficulties. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE)

About
  • SSPE is a rare, severe complication of the measles virus.
  • It typically presents in early adolescence and has a progressive course with high mortality.
  • Vaccination has reduced measles cases, but SSPE remains a concern due to measles re-emergence.

Pathophysiology
  • Caused by the measles virus, which is highly contagious and transmitted via aerosols.
  • The latency period ranges from 6-8 years post-infection, with shorter periods in younger children.
  • The virus targets lymphocytes and epithelial cells, causing significant immunosuppression.
  • SSPE is associated with a poor cellular immune response and persistent viral presence in the CNS.
  • Neuronal entry and infection mechanisms are not fully understood; mutations in the virus may facilitate evasion of the immune response.

Clinical Features
  • Symptoms typically arise 6-8 years after measles infection, starting with cognitive decline.
  • Early signs include personality changes, poor school performance, and lethargy.
  • Stage I: Personality and behavioural changes, including irritability, dementia, lethargy, social withdrawal, and speech regression.
  • Stage II: Progressive decline in motor function characterized by myoclonus, dyskinesia, and dystonia.
  • Stage III: Development of extrapyramidal symptoms, posturing, and spasticity.
  • Stage IV: Akinetic mutism, autonomic failure, or transition to a vegetative state.
  • Progressive motor function decline occurs, with myoclonus and focal paralysis.
  • Patients may develop seizures, leading to vegetative states or akinetic mutism.
  • Visual symptoms may precede other signs, including retinal lesions and vision loss.
  • Atypical presentations can involve psychiatric symptoms and rapid decline, especially in younger patients.

questions.text: Match the following conditions with their respective EEGs. 1) Focal seizure a) 2) Absence seizure b) 3) Hypsarrythmia c) 4) Periodic sharp wave complexes d)
questions.explanation:
Focal seizure

-EEG shows localized spikes or sharp waves in the region of the brain corresponding to the seizure onset.

Absence seizure

-EEG exhibits 3 Hz spike-and-slow wave discharges, typically generalized and symmetric.

Hypsarrythmia

-EEG presents chaotic, bursts of bilateral asynchronous high-amplitude slow waves interspersed with spikes followed by generalized voltage attenuation.

Periodic sharp wave complexes

-EEG reveals generalized synchronized high-voltage sharp waves occurring at 1–2 Hz.

questions.text: A 62 y/o man presents with rapid cognitive decline, visual disturbances, and myoclonus. An EEG shows localized frontal intermittent rhythmical delta activity (FIRDA) that evolves to periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWC) after a few weeks. Based on this presentation and EEG findings, which of the following conditions is most likely associated with his symptoms?
A 2-day-old infant born at 39 weeks gestation is being evaluated for seizures, and there is a family history of seizures. What is the most common type of seizure seen in newborns?

A 25 y/o woman with a history of catamenial epilepsy reports an increase in seizure frequency just before her menstrual period. She is currently taking carbamazepine and is newly started on OCPs for contraception. What is the most appropriate advice for her regarding her current situation?

options.label: B
options.text: Switch to phenytoin for better control.

options.label: C
options.text: Consider alternative contraception methods due to carbamazepine's effect on oral contraceptives.

options.label: D
options.text: Stop all antiseizure medications while trying to conceive.

questions.correct_answer: C. Consider alternative contraception methods due to carbamazepine's effect on oral contraceptives.
questions.explanation:
Catamenial Epilepsy
  • Increased seizure frequency around menses due to estrogen/progesterone effects or antiseizure drug level changes.
  • Some women may require increased antiseizure drug dosages during menses.
  • Natural progestins or intramuscular medroxyprogesterone may benefit certain women.

Pregnancy
  • ~50% of women experience unchanged seizure frequency; ~30% may increase, and ~20% decrease.
  • Monitoring of serum antiseizure drug levels is essential during pregnancy.
  • Lamotrigine and levetiracetam are recommended as first-line monotherapy for generalized and focal onset seizures.
  • The higher teratogenic risk with multiple antiseizure drugs is noted.
  • Valproic acid is strongly associated with adverse fetal outcomes and is thus contraindicated in pregnancy.
  • Folate supplementation (1–4 mg/d) is recommended due to antifolate effects of anticonvulsants.
  • Enzyme-inducing drugs (phenytoin, carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, topiramate, phenobarbital, primidone) may cause vitamin K deficiency in newborns. Hence mothers should take oral vitamin K, and infants should receive intramuscular vitamin K at birth.

Contraception
  • Certain antiseizure medications (carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbital, topiramate) reduce oral contraceptive efficacy via enzyme induction.
  • Alternative contraception methods (IUDs, long-acting reversible contraceptives) should be considered.

Breast-Feeding
  • Antiseizure medications are excreted in breast milk at varying levels (5% for valproic acid to 300% for levetiracetam).
  • Encouraged to breastfeed unless infant shows signs of drug effects (e.g., lethargy, poor feeding).

questions.text: A 10 y/o boy presents to the clinic with a history of seizures characterised by stiffness and rhythmic jerking of the entire body that occur multiple times a week. He has tried several medications but continues to experience seizures. Which of the following would be the most appropriate first-line treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type of Seizure

First-Line Treatments

Generalized-Onset Tonic-Clonic
  • Lamotrigine (Option B)
  • Valproic acid

Focal
  • Lamotrigine
  • Carbamazepine (Option C ruled out)
  • Oxcarbazepine
  • Eslicarbazepine
  • Phenytoin
  • Levetiracetam

Typical Absence
  • Valproic acid
  • Ethosuximide (Option A ruled out)
  • Lamotrigine

Atypical Absence, Myoclonic, Atonic
  • Valproic acid
  • Lamotrigine
  • Topiramate (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which statement about Mesial Temporal Lobe Epilepsy Syndrome is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: EEG may show unilateral or bilateral anterior temporal spikes.

options.label: B
options.text: MRI typically reveals an enlarged hippocampus with trilaminar architecture.

options.label: C
options.text: It is often refractory to anticonvulsants but may respond well to surgical intervention.

options.label: D
options.text: Auras, postictal disorientation and memory loss can occur.

questions.correct_answer: B. MRI typically reveals an enlarged hippocampus with trilaminar architecture.
questions.explanation:
Mesial Temporal lobe Epilepsy Syndrome

History
  • Often associated with a history of febrile seizures
  • Rarely involves generalised seizures
  • A family history of epilepsy may be present
  • Seizures can remit but may reoccur
  • Typically has an early onset

Clinical Observations(Option D ruled out)
  • Auras are commonly experienced.
  • Postictal disorientation.
  • Behavioural arrest or staring episodes.
  • Memory loss can occur.
  • Presence of complex automatisms.
  • Dysphasia may occur if the focus is in the dominant hemisphere.
  • Unilateral posturing is observed.

Laboratory Studies
  • EEG may show unilateral or bilateral anterior temporal spikes. (Option A ruled out)
  • Interictal PET scans reveal hypometabolism.
  • Ictal SPECT scans demonstrate hyperperfusion.
  • Intracranial amobarbital (Wada) test may indicate material-specific memory deficits.

MRI Findings
  • The hippocampus appears smaller with increased signal on T2-weighted sequences.
  • Loss of the trilaminar architecture of the hippocampus. (Option B)
  • Reduced size of the temporal lobe
  • Enlargement of the temporal horn.

Pathologic Findings
  • Characterized by a selective loss of specific cell populations within the hippocampus in most cases
  • Dispersion of the granule cell layer and gliosis are noted.

Treatment
  • Refractory to anticonvulsants.
  • Responds well to Surgical intervention. (Option C ruled out) ​​​

questions.text: A 30 y/o man is brought to the neurology clinic for evaluation after a brief period of unconsciousness. He is awake and alert during the examination. An EEG is performed while his eyes are closed. What is the frequency range recorded in the patient’s EEG?
questions.explanation:
Normal Brain Electrical Activity

Wave

Situation

Frequency

Alpha

(Option A)

Awake with eyes closed

8–13 Hz

Beta

(Option B ruled out)

Most frequently seen. Enhanced in drowsiness and sedative drugs like benzodiazepines.

>13 Hz

Theta

(Option D ruled out)

When sleeping. Drifting to sleep.

NREM Stage 1 sleep

4–8 Hz

Sigma

Also called as sleep spindles (associated with K complexes)

Deeper sleep

NREM Stage 2 sleep

12–14 Hz

Delta

(Option C ruled out)

NREM Stage 3 sleep

Deepest sleep

<4 Hz

questions.text: A 7 y/o girl presents to the pediatric neurology clinic with a history of multiple seizure types. Her parents report that she has experienced GTCS, atonic seizures where she suddenly drops to the ground, and atypical absence seizures. The child has also shown signs of cognitive impairment. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Characterized by bilateral myoclonic jerks that are most frequent in the morning.

options.label: B
options.text: The EEG findings show diffuse, symmetric, bilateral 4 to 6 Hz polyspike and wave discharges.

options.label: C
options.text: Valproate and Topiramate are used in treatment.

options.label: D
options.text: The condition typically presents in early adolescence.

questions.correct_answer: C. Valproate and Topiramate are used in treatment.
questions.explanation:
Characteristics

Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome

Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME/ JANZ Syndrome)

Onset

Occurs in children

Early adolescence (Option D ruled out)

Cause

Associated with various CNS dysfunction causes (e.g., de novo mutations, developmental abnormalities, perinatal hypoxia)

Unknown cause; polygenic factors suggested

Seizure Types

Multiple seizure types, including generalized tonic-clonic, atonic, and atypical absence seizures

Primarily bilateral myoclonic jerks; may also have generalized tonic-clonic and absence seizures

Myoclonic Seizures

Not a primary feature

Most frequent in the morning after awakening; can be provoked by sleep deprivation. (Option A ruled out)

Consciousness

Impaired cognitive function in most cases

Preserved unless myoclonus is severe

EEG Findings

Shows slow (<3 Hz) spike-and-wave discharges.

Shows diffuse, symmetric, bilateral 4 to 6 Hz polyspike and wave discharges, predominantly in the fronto-central region. (Option B ruled out)

Ictal EEG recordings reveal 10-16 Hz polyspike discharges that correlate with myoclonic jerks.

Treatment

Valproate, lamotrigine, and topiramate

Valproic acid

questions.text: A 25 y/o man is brought to the ED after experiencing a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. An EEG is performed after the seizure. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the EEG findings associated with his seizure?

options.label: A
options.text: The interictal EEG is often normal in patients.

options.label: B
options.text: During the tonic phase, the EEG typically shows a progressive increase in generalized low-voltage fast activity.

options.label: C
options.text: The postictal EEG usually reveals localized spikes corresponding to the seizure focus.

options.label: D
options.text: The EEG during the clonic phase shows continuous high-amplitude activity without interruption.

questions.correct_answer: B. During the tonic phase, the EEG typically shows a progressive increase in generalized low-voltage fast activity.
questions.explanation:
Focal Seizure- EEG

GTCS- EEG
  • The routine interictal EEG in patients with focal seizures is often normal. (Option A ruled out)
  • It may show brief discharges, such as epileptiform spikes or sharp waves.
  • Focal seizures can arise from areas like the medial temporal lobe or inferior frontal lobe, which may be distant from the scalp.
  • As a result, the EEG recorded during the seizure may be nonlocalizing.
  • The region of seizure onset can be identified using surgically placed intracranial electrodes.
  • During the tonic phase, the EEG shows a progressive increase in generalized low-voltage fast activity. (Option B)
  • This is followed by generalized high-amplitude polyspike discharges.
  • In the clonic phase, high-amplitude activity is typically interrupted by slow waves, creating a spike-and-slow-wave pattern. (Option D ruled out)
  • Generalized seizures tend to terminate synchronously across widespread brain regions.
  • The postictal EEG displays diffuse suppression of all cerebral activity, followed by slowing that gradually recovers as the patient awakens. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 25 y/o patient faints while standing in a crowded, hot room. Before fainting, he felt dizzy, sweaty, and nauseous. He regains consciousness quickly without any prolonged confusion or disorientation afterwards. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's fainting episode?
questions.explanation:
Features

Vasovagal Syncope (Neurally Mediated Syncope)

Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizures (GTCS)

Cause

It results from a reflex that alters autonomic outflow, leading to bradycardia, vasodilation, and reduced cardiac output. This lowers systemic blood pressure and causes cerebral hypoperfusion, leading to syncope.

GTCS are caused by widespread abnormal electrical activity in the brain, leading to both tonic (stiffening) and clonic (jerking) muscle contractions.

Triggers

Emotional stress, pain, standing upright for long periods, warm environments, dehydration, blood loss, and sight of blood.

GTCS can occur without clear triggers.

Pathophysiology

Increased parasympathetic outflow (vagal activation) and inhibition of sympathetic outflow result in bradycardia and hypotension. Cerebral blood flow falls below compensatory limits, causing loss of consciousness.

Seizures begin abruptly, often without warning. The tonic phase involves sustained muscle contraction, leading to symptoms like the "ictal cry" due to vocal cord contraction. The clonic phase features rhythmic jerking as muscles relax intermittently.

Symptoms
  • Premonitory: Dizziness, lightheadedness, nausea, yawning, sweating, pallor, and palpitations.
  • During the event: Transient loss of consciousness, uprolling of the eyes, dilated pupils, possible muscle jerks (myoclonus), and rarely, urinary or faecal incontinence.
  • EEG pattern: "Slow-flat-slow" pattern with high-amplitude slow waves, followed by EEG flattening.
  • Premonitory: Some patients have vague premonitory symptoms, but stereotypical auras are rare.
  • During the event: Tonic contraction followed by clonic jerking. The patient may experience cyanosis, tongue biting, loss of bladder/bowel control, and increased heart rate and blood pressure.
  • Postictal: Period of confusion lasting minutes to hours, fatigue, headache, muscle soreness, and incontinence. Postictal confusion is a prominent feature.
  • EEG pattern: Low-voltage fast activity during the tonic phase, followed by a spike-and-slow-wave pattern during the clonic phase. Postictal suppression of brain activity is observed.

Recovery

Quick recovery of consciousness without prolonged confusion. Postictal confusion and hallucinations are rare.

GTCS has a prolonged postictal phase with confusion and fatigue.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with brief episodes of sudden flexion of the trunk and limbs, lasting a few seconds. EEG shows hypsarrhythmia, and during the episodes, there's marked background suppression on the EEG. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23 y/o patient presents with sudden, brief muscle jerks involving both arms. EEG shows bilaterally synchronous spike-and-slow-wave discharges. The patient has a history of consuming poor-quality beef. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7 y/o child is brought to the clinic due to frequent episodes of "daydreaming" during school, which last for a few seconds and are accompanied by subtle eyelid blinking. The episodes occur several times a day, and the child has no recollection of these events. An EEG shows 3-Hz generalized spike-and-slow-wave discharges. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Typical Absence Seizures (Option A)

Atypical Absence Seizures (Option B ruled out)
  • Characteristics: Sudden, brief lapses of consciousness without postural control loss, lasting seconds.
  • Motor Signs: Subtle, bilateral motor signs such as eyelid blinking, chewing, or small clonic hand movements.
  • Onset: Common in children (ages 4–10) or early adolescence, occurring hundreds of times a day.
  • Clinical Presentation: May appear as "daydreaming" and poor school performance, often misdiagnosed as attention deficit disorder.
  • EEG Findings: Generalized 3-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharges.
  • Provoked By: Hyperventilation may induce seizures and EEG discharges.
  • Treatment: Valproate (drug of choice)
    • Valproate-associated fulminant hepatic failure (younger the age, higher the risk)
    • Ethosuximide is used (especially in <2 years).
  • Characteristics: Longer, less abrupt lapses of consciousness with more noticeable motor signs.
  • EEG Findings: Slower (<2.5 Hz) generalized spike-and-slow-wave discharges, plus other abnormalities.
  • Association: Linked to structural brain abnormalities and often co-occurs with mental retardation or neurologic dysfunction.
  • Treatment Response: Less responsive to anticonvulsants compared to typical absence seizures.

questions.text: A 35 y/o woman experiences sudden unresponsiveness during conversations, followed by repetitive hand movements and lip-smacking. Afterwards, she seems confused and does not remember the event. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: C. Focal Seizure with Impaired Awareness

questions.text: A 32 y/o woman experiences involuntary movements that begin in her right hand and progressively spread to her right arm and face. She remains fully aware throughout the episode. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40 y/o man collapses suddenly while walking and experiences a brief period of unconsciousness. His family notes that his body became completely limp before he fell. When he regains consciousness, he is confused and has a headache. What type of seizure does he most likely have?
questions.explanation:
Classification of Generalised Seizures

Generalised seizures are characterised by abnormal electrical activity that rapidly spreads across both hemispheres of the brain.

Tonic-Clonic Seizures    (Option B ruled out)

These can occur alone or in combination with other seizure types. Involves muscle stiffening (tonic phase), followed by rhythmic jerking (clonic phase).

Absence Seizures

Typical: Brief lapses in consciousness, without loss of postural control. Common in children. May be mistaken for daydreaming and attention deficit disorder.

Atypical: Longer episodes, slower onset/offset, may involve other motor symptoms.

With Special Features: Specific characteristics like eyelid flutter or additional movements.

Myoclonic Seizures    (Option D ruled out)

Sudden jerking movements of muscles.

Myoclonic-Atonic: Jerks followed by loss of muscle tone.

Myoclonic-Tonic: Jerks accompanied by muscle stiffening.

Atonic Seizures (Option C)

Sudden loss of muscle tone, leading to falls. These seizures are brief but pose a high risk of injury due to the sudden nature of the fall.

Clonic Seizures (Option A ruled out)

Rhythmic jerking without the initial tonic phase.

Tonic Seizures

Increased muscle tone with impaired awareness. Usually seen as a part of epilepsy syndrome.

Epileptic spasm

They typically occur in infants and are marked by sudden, forceful contractions of the muscles, particularly those of the trunk. The spasms often occur in clusters(5-50), especially upon waking, and are associated with widespread brain abnormalities.

questions.text: A 45 y/o man experiences sudden visual disturbances, seeing flashing lights and coloured shapes, but remains fully awake during the episode. After a few seconds, the sensations subside. Which type of seizure is most likely?
questions.correct_answer: A. Focal seizure with retained awareness
questions.explanation:
Classification of Focal Seizures

Focal seizures originate from a specific area in one hemisphere of the brain.

Classification by Awareness

Focal Seizures with Retained Awareness

No loss of awareness during the seizure, symptoms depend on the brain area affected like visual disturbances, motor jerking, and sensory changes. (Option A)

Focal Seizures with Impaired Awareness

Awareness is impaired, often starting with a blank stare and involving automatisms like lip-smacking, picking, chewing and other repetitive movements. (Option B ruled out)

Motor vs Nonmotor Onset (In Focal Seizures with Retained Awareness)

Motor Onset

Observable movements like tonic, clonic, or myoclonic jerking.

Special Features

  • Jacksonian March: Progressive motor involvement starting in a specific body part.
 
  • Todd’s Paralysis: Temporary weakness after a focal seizure.
  • Epilepsia Partialis Continua: Continuous focal seizures resistant to medication.

Nonmotor Onset

Sensory, autonomic, or emotional changes without visible movement.

Evolution

Focal Seizures Evolving into generalised Seizures

Start focally but spread to both hemispheres, often leading to generalised tonic-clonic seizures.

questions.text: A 28 y/o woman is witnessed having a seizure. After a brief period of muscle stiffening, she begins to have jerking movements. The episode lasts about one minute, and she becomes unresponsive with flaccid muscles afterwards. She later regains consciousness but is confused. Which phase of the seizure involves alternating muscle contraction and relaxation?
questions.explanation:
Generalised Tonic-Clonic Seizure - Features

Tonic phase (Option A ruled out)

Clonic phase (Option B)

Post-ictal period (Option C ruled out)
  • Muscle contraction throughout the body.
  • Ictal cry: Loud sound from laryngeal contraction.
  • Cyanosis: Due to respiratory compromise.
  • Tongue biting and sympathetic activity (increased heart rate, blood pressure).
  • Lasts about 10-20 seconds
  • Alternating muscle contraction and relaxation.
  • Relaxation periods gradually increase until the seizure ends (usually lasts <1 minute).
  • Unresponsiveness and muscle flaccidity.
  • Excessive salivation and laboured breathing.
  • Incontinence may occur.
  • Gradual return of consciousness, with confusion, headache, fatigue, and muscle pain.
